abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Integrated Hill
            Farming Development Project for Pakistan was satisfactory.
            The project achieved or substantially exceeded its physical
            targets, its impact on institutional development was
            partial, sustainability is likely, and both the Bank and
            Borrower performed satisfactorily. Several lessons can be
            learned from this project. First, the design of area
            development projects needs to distinguish between
            areas/activities where the market mechanism could bring
            about an efficient allocation of resources and where it
            cannot do so because of market failures or externalities.
            Second, integration between different departments/agencies
            is difficult but necessary and would be facilitated by the
            close involvement of local communities in planning and
            implementation. Third, appropriate technical packages must
            be available before the start of a project. Fourth, a more
            sustainable approach to rural development needs to be
            developed. Fifth, the T & V system of extension needs to
            be modified to local circumstances. Lastly, road design in
            geologically fragile areas should incorporate features and
            mechanical structures which minimize environmental damage
            and reduce maintenance costs.
